criteria: Ability to identify healthy food options
Ability to make healthy food choices in different settings
Consideration of dietary needs and preferences
descriptions: Student cannot identify any healthy food options.
Student can identify very few healthy food options (1-2) with significant prompting.
Student can identify some healthy food options (3-4) with some prompting.
Student can identify several healthy food options (5-6) with minimal prompting.
Student can independently identify many healthy food options and explain why they are healthy.
Student can comprehensively identify a wide variety of healthy food options, explain why they are healthy, and compare them to less healthy alternatives.
Student does not demonstrate understanding of nutritional information (e.g., calories, macronutrients, vitamins).
Student demonstrates very limited understanding of nutritional information, requiring significant assistance.
Student demonstrates some understanding of nutritional information, but struggles to apply it to food choices.
Student demonstrates a solid understanding of nutritional information and can apply it to basic food choices.
Student demonstrates a strong understanding of nutritional information and can apply it to complex food choices and dietary needs.
Student demonstrates expert understanding of nutritional information, can apply it to a wide range of food choices, and can critically evaluate nutritional claims.
Student consistently makes unhealthy food choices in all settings.
Student makes unhealthy food choices most of the time and requires significant guidance to make healthier choices.
Student occasionally makes healthy food choices, but inconsistently and often with prompting.
Student makes healthy food choices in some settings (e.g., at home) but struggles in others (e.g., at restaurants).
Student consistently makes healthy food choices in a variety of settings with minimal prompting.
Student consistently makes healthy food choices in all settings and can advocate for healthy options in challenging environments.
Student does not consider dietary needs or preferences when making food choices.
Student shows minimal awareness of dietary needs and preferences.
Student shows some awareness of dietary needs and preferences, but struggles to apply it to food choices.
Student considers basic dietary needs and preferences (e.g., allergies, vegetarianism) when making food choices.
Student thoughtfully considers a variety of dietary needs and preferences when making food choices.
Student proactively seeks out and accommodates diverse dietary needs and preferences in various settings.
